metadata.case_name: Ouchterlony Valley Estates Ltd. & Ors. v. State of Kerala

facts.text: Appellants are Plantation Companies which grow their own tea in Tea Estates and sell their products.

Under Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act 11 of 1125, Sales-tax Officers assessed appellants to tax on turnover for different years including 1952-53 to 1956-57 for Ouchterlony Valley Estates Ltd.
Appellants urged before Sales-tax Officers that transactions not liable to sales-tax; pleas rejected.
Appellants appealed to Sales-Tax Appellate Tribunal, which concurred with Sales-tax Officers and confirmed assessments.
Appellants filed revision petitions under s.15(2) of Travancore Act before Kerala High Court, which dismissed them (judgment dated November 1961, I.L.R. 1960 Kerala 1395).
Appellant Ouchterlony Valley Estates Ltd. produces tea in own estates, sells by public auction at Fort Cochin (State of Madras); goods stored at godowns at Wellingdon Island (Travancore).

Procedure: Tea graded, weighed, packed in chests in estates, forwarded with garden invoices to godowns of Peirce Leslie & Co. Ltd. at Wellingdon Island. Brokers check weight, draw samples, group into lots, publish catalogues, advertise sale by public auction at Fort Cochin by samples with export rights.

Sale conducted by samples at Fort Cochin; confirmed to highest bidder (lot or brake). Buyer entitled to open chests, examine contents. Claims for difference/inferiority/quality/damage submitted not later than 5 p.m. on 3rd day before prompt day (9th day after sale) or 24 hrs before removal.
Payment on or before prompt day (10th day after sale) in Cochin. Delivery before 5 p.m. on 5th day after prompt day. Goods at seller's risk to sale price extent until then or removal.

Kerala High Court in Deputy Commissioner v. A.V. Thomas & Co. Ltd. held property passes at Fort Cochin but taxable in Travancore-Cochin as not outside sale under Art. 286(1)(a); binding on authorities.

Supreme Court reversed A.V. Thomas in A.V. Thomas & Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner (1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 608, A.I.R. 1965 S.C. 161), holding property passes on fall of hammer at Fort Cochin (Madras), outside sale for Travancore-Cochin.
Supreme Court in Malayalam Plantations Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner followed same view.
Matter heard first on 10th September 1964; adjourned for Rules of Tea Trade Association of Cochin.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sales of tea by public auction at Fort Cochin (Madras) with goods stored at Wellingdon Island (Travancore) are 'outside sales' under Art. 286(1)(a) for Travancore-Cochin sales tax, i.e., whether property in goods passes at Fort Cochin on fall of hammer or after inspection and acceptance at Wellingdon Island.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transactions not liable to sales tax as property passes at Fort Cochin on fall of hammer; outside sales for Travancore-Cochin.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(1)(a); Sale of Goods Act s.64(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Sales by sample under s.17 Sale of Goods Act; conditional/executory contract for unascertained goods; title passes only after buyer inspects and accepts goods at Wellingdon Island (Travancore), making inside sales.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sale of Goods Act ss.17(2),18,19,64(2); Benjamin on Sale; McManus v. Fortescue

respondent_arguments.text: Question of inside/outside sales urged at all stages; should be decided on merits; Tea Trade Rules (conditions 7,8,11,12,13) show acceptance after inspection.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Tea Trade Association Rules of Cochin

court_reasoning.text: Goods ascertained and existing (graded, weighed, packed, listed); not unascertained. Title passes per intention in contract terms (s.19 Sale of Goods Act). Tea Trade Rules show sale complete on fall of hammer (cond.7); buyer owns chests post-auction, can claim defects/rejection via arbitrator (conds.11,12,13); risk shifts post-prompt day (cond.23); resale on non-payment (cond.15).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Auction sale of ascertained goods complete on fall of hammer under s.64(2); not conditional on inspection/acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: A.V. Thomas Kerala HC decision no longer good law post-SC reversal; same facts as A.V. Thomas and Malayalam Plantations where property held to pass at Fort Cochin.

holdings.text: Title to goods passes to buyer under s.64(2) Sale of Goods Act on fall of hammer at Fort Cochin auction; sales are outside sales qua Travancore-Cochin, not taxable there.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.V. Thomas & Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax and Sales Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Reversed Kerala HC; property passes on fall of hammer at Fort Cochin; outside sale for Travancore-Cochin.

precedents_cited.case_name: Malayalam Plantations Ltd., Quilon v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Same view on tea auction sales; property passes at Fort Cochin.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deputy Commissioner v. A.V. Thomas & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Kerala HC held taxable in Travancore-Cochin; reversed by SC.
Auction with reserve price condition; fall of hammer subject to condition; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act 11 of 1125
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines outside sales; situs of taxable event where goods delivered for consumption if title passes elsewhere.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs passage of property in sale by sample/auction; complete on fall of hammer.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; Kerala High Court orders set aside; sales-tax levies by authorities held invalid as sales are outside sales under Art. 286(1)(a).
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of sales tax assessments and High Court dismissal of revisions.

key_quotes.text: the property in teas passed to the buyer under S. 64 of the Act as soon as the offer was accepted on fall of the hammer at Fort Cochin in the State of Madras
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on passage of title.

key_quotes.text: title to the goods passed to the buyer under s. 64(2) of the Act as soon as the sale was completed by the auctioneer announcing its completion by the fall of the hammer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Decisive reasoning rejecting respondent's conditional sale argument.
